meta.title: Congenital urachal abnormalities: cyst, sinus, and vesicourethral diverticulum

content:
Introduction

Congenital urachal anomalies occur due to incomplete obliteration of the urachus, a remnant of the allantois that connects the fetal bladder to the umbilicus.  These defects often remain asymptomatic but can present with complications (eg, infection, sinus tract formation) at any age.

Pathogenesis



In utero, the caudal yolk sac forms the allantois, a diverticulum that extends from the fetal bladder to the umbilicus.  As the bladder descends into the pelvis during embryologic development, the allantois stretches and becomes a thin, narrow tubular structure.  Normally, epithelial proliferation leads to obliteration of the allantois lumen by 12 weeks gestation, forming a fibrous cord known as the urachus.  However, inadequate epithelial proliferation results in complete or partial urachal patency (

figure 1
), as follows:



  • Complete urachal patency:  Results in an anatomic connection between the bladder and umbilicus.
  • Partial urachal patency:  Results in a urachus that is only open to the umbilicus (ie, urachal sinus), to the bladder (ie, urachal diverticulum), or centrally (ie, urachal cyst).

Clinical presentation



Clinical presentation depends on the location of the defect, as follows:



  • Patent urachus:  May be asymptomatic or present with persistent umbilical leakage of urine.
  • Urachal sinus:  May be asymptomatic or present with signs of infection, including a palpable midline abdominal mass with overlying erythema and purulent drainage.  Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) can occur.
  • Urachal cyst:  May be asymptomatic or present with signs of infection, similar to a urachal sinus.  Over time, fluid accumulates in the urachal cyst and can become infected with gram-positive skin flora (eg, Staphylococcus aureus) or gram-negative Enterobacteriaceae.
  • Urachal diverticulum:  May be asymptomatic or present with recurrent urinary tract infections due to urinary stasis.

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected congenital urachal anomalies (eg, adolescent with painful midline lower abdominal mass), ultrasonography should be performed to visualize the defect between the bladder and umbilicus.  CT scan may be necessary to better characterize anatomic relationships between structures and identify complications (eg, abscess or sinus tract formation).  In addition, imaging should evaluate for associated genitourinary tract abnormalities that could complicate management.  Though not necessary for diagnosis, laboratory evaluation may show leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers (eg, C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate), consistent with infection.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for congenital urachal anomalies includes other midline abdominal masses, with or without umbilical drainage, as follows:



  • Patent omphalomesenteric duct:  Similar to the allantois, the omphalomesenteric duct is a diverticulum of the yolk sac that extends from the midgut to the umbilicus and normally involutes in early gestation.  However, persistent patency results in umbilical leakage of stool.
  • Omphalitis:  This infection of the umbilical cord stump results in purulent drainage, erythema, and induration.
  • Umbilical granuloma:  Excess granulation tissue results in a pedunculated mass that does not connect to the abdominal cavity.  Serous umbilical moisture may develop.
  • Umbilical hernia:  This midline abdominal mass protrudes with increased abdominal pressure and is typically reducible.

Management



Although reassurance and observation are reasonable in some asymptomatic cases, surgical excision is generally preferred due to the risk for infection and rare malignancy.  Symptomatic (ie, infected) cases require antibiotic therapy prior to surgical excision.  The prognosis is excellent following surgical excision.

Summary



Congenital urachal anomalies occur due to incomplete obliteration of the urachus, a remnant of the allantois that connects the fetal bladder to the umbilicus.  These defects often remain asymptomatic but can present with complications (eg, infection, sinus tract formation) at any age.  Diagnosis involves abdominal imaging (eg, ultrasonography, CT scan) to visualize the cyst and its relationship to surrounding structures (eg, bladder, umbilicus); management involves surgical excision.
